Metal-oxide interaction is crucial in catalyst performance. Using MOF as precursor can improve the metal-oxide interface on the catalysts. This work explores the properties of the MOF-derived Cu-Zn-Zr catalysts (CZZ-HN, CZZ-C Z-HNPs, CZZ-ZB, CZZ-Z and CZZ-U) in the hydrogenation of CO2 to CH3OH with reference to the conventional catalysts (CZZ-CP) prepared by co-precipitation. The catalyst structure is found to be closely related to the catalyst composition and the MOF type. The evaluation results imply that the CO2 hydrogenation activity is related to the number of surface Cu sites, and different Cu sites influence the product distribution. Among the investigated catalysts, the metal-oxide interface is greatly enhanced on CZZ-HN due to the proper match of element composition and MOF type (high amount of Cu with Cu-MOF precursor), which shows improved STYCH3OH and TOFCH3OH compared with CZZ-CP. This study verifies the enhancement of metal-oxide interface by the MOF-derivation method, and inspires further optimization of catalyst structure by matching synthesis formula and MOF types for various reactions. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords CO2 hydrogenation MOF-based Cu-ZnO-ZrO2 catalysts CH3OH synthesis Metal-oxide interface Data availability The data that has been used is confidential. 1 Introduction The massive accumulation of CO2 greenhouse gases in the atmosphere has caused serious environmental problems such as global warming and climate change [1,2]. The utilization of CO2 as a non-traditional renewable carbon source is of great significance to reduce CO2 emissions [3]. Using renewable hydrogen and CO2 via catalytic hydrogenation to produce valuable fuels and chemicals is an effective way to alleviate the greenhouse effect and realize carbon cycle. Among the hydrogenation products, methanol is a liquid fuel which is easy to store and transport, and is an important chemical for the production of olefins, gasoline, biodiesel, etc. [4,5]. In addition, methanol can also generate electricity in direct methanol fuel cells. Therefore, the development of efficient CH3OH synthesis catalysts from CO2 is critical to reduce carbon emissions and provide fossil energy alternatives. Cu-based catalysts have been widely used in methanol synthesis via CO2 hydrogenation. Their catalytic activity is closely related to the interface between copper and metal oxides (e.g., ZnO, ZrO2), and the metal-oxide interface or surface bimetallic alloy is considered to be important active sites [6,7]. Although the actual active site is controversial, increasing the copper-metal oxide interface is an effective strategy to improve the catalytic activity of methanol production. Among various Cu-based catalysts, Cu-Zn-Zr catalysts exhibit excellent catalytic performance [17–21] owing to its unique properties such as improved Cu dispersion, strong interaction between Zn/Zr and Cu [12,13], enhanced hydrogen spillover [14,23,26], adjustable alkalinity with enhanced adsorption of CO2 and related intermediates, good water resistance [8,9] and thermal stability [10,11]. The interfaces of Cu-ZnO, Cu-ZrO2 as well as ZnO-ZrO2 are considered as the active sites [15,20–22]. Cu sites could be stabilized by ZrO2 and provide higher hydrogen dissociation activity, while ZnO-ZrO2 and Cu-ZnO interfaces are related to methanol formation steps. Therefore, it is intuitive to enhance the catalytic performance by enhancing the metal-oxide interfaces. Metal-organic framing materials (MOFs) have been widely studied in the field of catalysis, due to their porous structure and rich metal sites. By controlling the synthesis conditions, the unstable MOF nodes or linkers can be converted into stable metal oxide or hollow porous carbons [15]. Meanwhile, the frame structure can constraint the metal nanoparticles to the pore or cage, thereby increasing the metal-oxide interface [16]. Yu et al. [22] prepared the Cu-ZrO2 catalyst using HKUST-1 as the precursor of Cu by forming highly dispersed Cu nanoclusters on the ZrO2 surface. The highly dispersed Cu nanoclusters not only provided a large number of efficient active sites for CO2 hydrogenation, but also generated more Cu-ZrO2 interface, thus improving the selectivity and STY of methanol. Liu et al. [23] used UiO-66 as the precursor of Zr to synthesize Cu@ZrOx with a 3D porous skeleton. The unit of UiO-66 evolved into a stable tetragonal ZrO2 phase, and a strong metal-support interaction (SMSI) was obtained at the Cu-ZrOx interface. Yin et al. [24] synthesized Pd/ZnO using Pd@ZIF-8 as precursor, and the SMSI formed at the Pd-ZnO interface led to high methanol formation activity. The above literature show that using MOF as precursor can improve the metal-oxide interface on the catalysts, and the rich interfaces can effectively improve the activity of methanol synthesis. In light of the interface enhancement, it is viable to improve the methanol synthesis performance of Cu-Zn-Zr catalyst by MOF-derivation. To the best of our knowledge, the MOF-derived Cu-Zn-Zr catalysts have not been reported. Considering the advantages of the catalyst syntheses from MOF precursors, this work aims to explore the properties of the MOF-derived Cu-Zn-Zr catalysts in the hydrogenation of CO2 to methanol. Different MOF precursors (HKUST-1 (Cu), ZIF-8 (Zn) and UiO-66 (Zr)) are used as sacrificial templates. The physicochemical properties of the metal-oxide interface on the catalyst are investigated through characterizations, and their correlation with catalytic properties is established. This work systematically investigated the MOF-derived Cu-Zn-Zr catalysts in the methanol synthesis process from CO2, and the obtained results will inspire us to optimize the metal-oxide interface in vario us reactions. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst preparation Five Cu-ZnO-ZrO2 (CZZ) catalysts (Cu/Zn/Zr=6/3/1, CuO 56.4wt%) were synthesized using the top-down method, derived from HKUST-1 (Cu), ZIF-8 (Zn), and UiO-66 (Zr), with a catalyst prepared by coprecipitation (CZZ-CP) serving as a reference. Two different synthesis methods were used for the HKUST-1 and ZIF-8 derived catalysts, and one method was used for the UiO-66 derived catalyst. The MOF-derived catalysts were synthesized by dissolving different Cu salts, Zn salts, Zr salts, or their respective nanoparticles and coordinating agents in organic solvents, followed by a hydrothermal reaction or direct drying. The schematic diagram of the synthesis procedures is shown in Fig. 1 . Specifically, the preparation of CZZ-HKUST-1@Nitrate (CZZ-HN) involved dissolving Cu(NO3)2·3H2O, Zn(NO3)2·6H2O, Zr(NO3)4·5H2O, and 1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylic acid in ethanol, followed by a hydrothermal reaction. CZZ-HKUST-1@NPs (CZZ-HNPs) used pre-synthesized PVP-stabilized ZrO2 and ZnO nanoparticles and Cu(NO3)2·3H2O in the hydrothermal reaction. CZZ-ZIF-8-BTC (CZZ-ZB) was synthesized using Cu(NO3)2·3H2O, ZIF-8, Zn(NO3)2·6H2O, Zr(NO3)4·5H2O, and 1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylic acid with a hydrothermal treatment. CZZ-ZIF-8 (CZZ-Z) was obtained by dissolving Cu(NO3)2·3H2O, Zn(NO3)2·6H2O, Zr(NO3)4·5H2O, and 2-methylimidazole in methanol, followed by washing and drying steps. CZZ-UiO-66 (CZZ-U) was prepared by dissolving Cu(NO3)2·3H2O, Zn(NO3)2·6H2O, ZrCl4, and terephthalic acid in a mixed solvent, followed by a hydrothermal reaction. Details of the catalyst preparation could be found in the supplementary materials.” 2.2 Catalyst characterization The catalysts were characterized by X-ray diffraction (XRD), N2-physical adsorption, temperature-programmed reduction (TPR), temperature-programmed desorption (CO2-TPD), N2O chemisorption, and X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS). Details of the characterizations could be found in the supplementary materials. 2.3 Catalytic evaluation The synthesized catalysts were evaluated in the CO2 hydrogenation in a fixed-bed reactor. The reaction was allowed to occur from 493 K to 613 K under 4 MPa after the reduction in H2 at 573 K for 2 h. The GHSV was 5400 mL g−1 cat h−1 and the H2/CO2 ratio was 3. The products were analyzed online by a gas chromatograph (Techcomp, GC7900) equipped with a flame ionization detector (FID, TM-PLOT Q) and a thermal conductivity detector (TCD, TDX-01). The products were found to possess a carbon balance above 95 % compared with the inlet carbon. The CO2 conversion (X CO2), the product selectivitiy (S p), the space time yield of CH3OH (STYCH3OH), the TOF of converted CO2 (TOFCO2) and the TOF of produced CH3OH (TOFCH3OH) were calculated by the following equations: X C O 2 ( % ) = F C O 2 , in − F C O 2 , out F C O 2 , in × 100 % S p ( % ) = F P F C O 2 , in − F C O 2 , out × 100 % ST Y C H 3 OH = X C O 2 × S C H 3 OH × V C O 2 × M w C H 3 OH m cat × M v TO F C O 2 ( s − 1 ) = X C O 2 × V C O 2 × M w C u m cat × M v × Cu wt % × D TO F C H 3 OH ( s − 1 ) = TO F C O 2 × S C H 3 OH Where F CO2,in and F CO2,out are the molar flow rate of CO2 at the inlet and the outlet, respectively, F P is the product molar flow rate at the outlet, V CO2 is the volume flow rate of CO2, Mw CH3OH and Mw Cu are the molecular weight of CH3OH and Cu, respectively. Mv is the molar volume of the ideal gas (22,400 mol/L), m cat is the weight of catalyst, D is the dispersion of Cu and S Cu. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Physiochemical properties The N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms and pore size distributions of the reduced catalyst are shown in Fig. 2 . The isotherms are between Type II and Type IV. Combining the pore size distribution results, CZZ-CP, CZZ-HN and CZZ-Z exhibit obvious pore size peaks, implying the existence of mesopores. CZZ-U, CZZ-ZB and CZZ-HNPs barely exhibit any micro- or mesopores, implying that the three isotherms are closer to Type II, and large pores mainly exist over the three catalysts. The surface area, pore volume, and average pore size of the catalysts are shown in Table 1 , and the data of HKUST-1, ZIF-8, and UiO-66 are provided as a reference. Compared with the MOFs, the surface area and pore volume decrease significantly after high temperature calcination. CZZ-HN exhibits similar surface area and average pore diameter with the reference CZZ-CP prepared by coprecipitation, and the others exhibit lower surface area and larger average pore diameter. The difference in the texture properties is closely related to the synthesis procedures. In the syntheses of CZZ-ZB, CZZ-Z and CZZ-U, the MOF ligands of Zn and Zr failed to form pore structures similar to ZIF-8 and UiO-66 due to the high proportion of Cu metal salt, resulting in an increase in the average pore diameter and a decrease in the surface area. In the synthesis of CZZ-HNPs, the existences of ZrO2 and ZnO NPs expands the pore structure, resulting in an increased average pore diameter and a reduced surface area. In the synthesis of CZZ-HN, where Cu exists in the MOF ligands of HKUST-1, the sacrifice process retains the MOF skeleton, leading to a relatively high surface area. The XRD profiles of the uncalcined and the reduced catalysts are shown in Fig. 3 . Characteristic peaks of the corresponding MOFs are present on the uncalcined samples of CZZ-HN, CZZ-HNPs and CZZ-Z. The characteristic peaks of UiO-66 are insignificant over the uncalcined CZZ-U due to the low amount of ZrO2. The reduced catalysts exhibit diffraction peaks at 43.3°, 50.4°, and 74.1°, corresponding to the crystalline facets of Cu (111), (200), and (220), respectively. The diffraction peaks at 31.8°, 34.4°, and 36.3° are observed on CZZ-CP and CZZ-HN, corresponding to the crystalline facets of ZnO (100), (002), and (101), respectively. The ZrO2 diffraction peaks are not observed over the two catalysts, indicating that ZrO2 exists in amorphous form. Diffraction peaks of both ZnO and ZrO2 are observed on CZZ-HNPs, CZZ-Z, and CZZ-U. The diffraction peak at 35° corresponds to ZrO2 (111) on CZZ-ZB, while the ZnO diffraction peaks are not observed, indicating that amorphous ZnO is formed from the precursor CuZn-BTC. The above results imply that the metal oxides arise after the calcination with the disappearance of MOF phases. The crystalline sizes of Cu calculated by the Scherrer equation are shown in Table 2 . The feature of the Cu crystalline size is similar with the trend of surface area that CZZ-HN exhibit similar Cu crystalline size with CZZ-CP, while the other catalysts exhibit larger Cu crystalline sizes. Due to the formation of large pore structure and low surface area in the syntheses of CZZ-HNPs, CZZ-ZB, CZZ-Z and CZZ-U, the Cu particles tend to grow in large size. 3.2 Reducibility and surface properties The H2-TPR profiles are shown in Fig. 4 (a). All the catalysts show a wide reduction peak in the range of 400–700 K. Because ZnO and ZrO2 are not reduced in this temperature range, the peaks correspond to the reduction of CuO. The broad reduction peaks can be deconvoluted into two peaks: low temperature peak (α) and high temperature peak (β), corresponding to the highly dispersed CuOx species with strong interaction with ZnO and/or ZrO2, and the bulk CuO species, respectively. Compared with CZZ-CP, the β peak of CZZ-HNPs and CZZ-U shifts slightly to higher temperature, which may be resulted from the large Cu crystalline size as evidenced from the XRD results [25,27]. On the contrary, although the Cu crystalline size over CZZ-Z is also larger than CZZ-CP, the β peak of CZZ-Z shifts slightly towards low temperature, possibly due to the strong interaction of Cu with ZnO and/or ZrO2, which could promote the reduction of CuO [10,28]. Similar result is observed over CZZ-HN. The peak deconvolution results are listed in Table 3 , along with the summary of the proportion of α peak. CZZ-HN possesses the significantly higher proportion of α peak than the other catalysts, indicating that the highly dispersed CuOx species may be rich over CZZ-HN. The CO2-TPD profiles of the reduced catalysts are shown in Fig. 4(b). A large desorption peak is observed at 471 K over CZZ-CP, corresponding to the weak adsorption site. The desorption temperatures and the peak areas of the MOF-derived catalysts are significantly lower than those of CZZ-CP, indicating that the weak adsorption strength and the amount of weak adsorption sites of the MOF-derived catalysts are lower than those of the conventional catalyst synthesized by coprecipitation. Besides the weak desorption peaks, a large strong desorption peak is observed over CZZ-HN at 766 K. The exposed Cu surface areas, Cu dispersions and Cu particle sizes obtained from N2O chemisorption are summarized in Table 2. Consistently with the XRD results, the Cu surface areas and dispersions of the MOF-derived catalysts are lower as compared to CZZ-CP. The Cu particle size obtained from N2O chemisorption is slightly smaller than the corresponding crystalline size obtained from XRD for each catalyst except CZZ-U, while the particle size of CZZ-U obtained from N2O is significantly larger than the crystalline size obtained from XRD. The difference in particle size and crystalline size arises from two reasons: firstly, XRD can only characterizes the size of the crystalline particles and the amorphous particles are not included; secondly, the crystalline size from XRD represents the bulk properties while the particle size from N2O chemisorption represents the surface properties. The smaller particle sizes from N2O chemisorption imply that small amorphous particles exist over the surfaces of CZZ-HN, CZZ-HNPs, CZZ-ZB and CZZ-Z, while the significantly larger particle size of CZZ-U implies that large particles agglomerate on the catalyst surface. The second TPR profile in N2O chemisorption represents the reducing properties of the surface species, and the results are shown in Fig. 5 and Table 4 . The profile of CZZ-CP can be deconvoluted into two peaks at 421 K and 458 K, corresponding to the reduction of the CuO sites with strong interactions with ZnO and/or ZrO2 and the independent CuO sites, respectively. Two reduction peaks are also present over CZZ-HN and CZZ-ZB; compared with CZZ-CP, both reduction peaks shift toward lower temperatures. Only one reduction peak is observed over CZZ-HNPs, CZZ-Z and CZZ-U, which should be attributed to the independent CuO sites, implying that the metal-oxide interaction is minor over CZZ-HNPs, CZZ-Z and CZZ-U. The reduction peak of CZZ-U is significantly higher, which also implies that large Cu particles exist over the surface of CZZ-U. The XPS spectra of the reduced catalyst are shown in Fig. 6 . The peak deconvolution results are exhibited in Tables 5 and 6 . The spectra of Cu 2p could be deconvoluted into two pairs of peaks. The peaks at 932.2 eV and 952.1 eV correspond to the 2p3/2 and 2p1/2 bands of the low-valent Cu (Cu+ and/or Cu0) species, and the peaks at 933.8 eV and 953.6 eV correspond to the 2p3/2 and 2p1/2 bands of the Cu2+ species. Compared to CZZ-CP, the peaks of CZZ-ZB and CZZ-U shift toward higher bands, while the peaks of CZZ-HNPs shift towards lower bands. The surface Cu valence states were evaluated qualitatively by the spectra of Cu-LMM. The surface amounts of Cu0, Cu+ and Cu2+ are summarized in Table 6. The Cu+ proportion follows the order of CZZ-HN > CZZ-CP > CZZ-ZB > CZZ-HNPs ∼ CZZ-Z > CZZ-U, which could reflect the strong interaction of Cu with the metal oxides. The Cu2+ proportion follows the order of CZZ-U > CZZ-ZB ∼ CZZ-HNPs > CZZ-Z ∼ CZZ-CP ∼ CZZ-HN. The presence of Cu2+ indicates that a certain number of oxygen vacancies were generated during the reduction process, which were easy to be occupied when exposed to the ambient environment. Therefore, the Cu2+ proportion could reflect the relative number of surface oxygen vacancies. The XPS spectra of Zr 3d could be deconvoluted into two peaks at 182.1 and 184.4 eV, corresponding to the 3d 5/2 and 3d 3/2 bands of Zr4+, respectively. Compared to CZZ-CP, the Zr 3d5/2 peaks of CZZ-HN and CZZ-HNPs shift towards lower band by 0.4 and 0.7 eV, respectively. Both the Cu and Zr binding energies of CZZ-HNPs shift towards lower bands, indicating that a large number of vacant sites are present on the catalyst surface, which were re-oxidized during the ex-situ transfer after reduction. The XPS spectra of O 1 s could be deconvoluted into two peats at 530.3 and 532.1 eV, which are attributed to lattice oxygen (Oγ) and surface oxygen (Oα). The ratio of Oα/Oγ are presented in Table 6, which could represent the relative amount of oxygen vacancies, and the order is consistent with the order of the surface Cu2+ proportion. The oxygen vacancies could estimate the degree of metal-oxide interface [29,30]. The surface ratios of Zn/Cu and Zr/Cu are summarized in Table 6. The ratios of Zn/Cu and Zr/Cu on CZZ-CP, CZZ-HN, and CZZ-Z are higher than the bulk ratios (Zn/Cu=0.5, Zr/Cu=0.16), indicating that Zn and Zr are enriched on the catalyst surface. In contrast, Zn is enriched on the surface of CZZ-HNPs while Zr is enriched inside the catalyst; Zr is enriched on the CZZ-ZB surface and Zn is enriched inside the catalyst. The significantly lower ratios of Zn/Cu and Zr/Cu on CZZ-U again verify the enrichment of Cu on the surface, in consistent with the XRD, TPR and N2O-chemisorption results. 3.3 Catalytic performance The CO2 conversion and the Arrhenius plot are shown in Fig. 7 , with the regressed apparent activation energy summarized in Table 7 . The MOF-derived catalysts showed reduced conversion compared with CZZ-CP mainly due to the reduced Cu surface area. The apparent activation energy follows the order of CZZ-Z > CZZ-HNPs > CZZ-ZB > CZZ-HN > CZZ-CP > CZZ-U. The product selectivities are shown in Fig. 8 (a)–(c), and the relationship between CH3OH selectivity and CO2 conversion is shown in Fig. 8(d). CZZ-U exhibits the highest CH3OH selectivity over the investigated temperature range with effective inhibition of reverse water-gas shift (RWGS). However, CZZ-U has the lowest activity due to the agglomeration of surface Cu; therefore, its selectivity is not comparable with other catalysts as shown in Fig. 8(d). To compare the intrinsic properties, the CH3OH selectivities are compared at low conversions. CZZ-HN exhibits the highest CH3OH selectivity, while CZZ-ZB exhibits slightly higher selectivity than CZZ-CP, CZZ-HNPs and CZZ-Z. The STYs of CH3OH and the TOF of produced CH3OH at 533 K are shown in Fig. 9 . CZZ-HN exhibits the highest STYCH3OH and the highest TOFCH3OH. Since CZZ-HN exhibits superior performance, the stability test was carried out on CZZ-HN at 533 K as shown in Fig. 10 . During the reaction of 320 h, both CO2 conversion and CH3OH selectivity are stable. It is found that the methanol production rate is not closely related to the MOF type; therefore, the catalyst performance should be correlated with the characterization results. By correlating the characterization results and the evaluation results, the Cu surface area, surface Cu valent states and the metal-oxide interactions would affect the catalytic performances. Cu surface area (S Cu) is important to measure the active site of the catalyst. The CO2 conversion is positively correlated with S Cu as shown in Fig. 11 (a), because the Cu site can activate CO2 and catalyze the hydrogenation of intermediates [31]. The amount of Cu surface site is closely related with the MOF type and the synthesis procedure. In the synthesis of CZZ-Z, CZZ-ZB and CZZ-U, the MOF skeleton of ZIF-8 and UiO-66 could not bear the high loading of Cu, and the calcination could not prevent the Cu agglomeration, resulting in large Cu particles and low S Cu. CZZ-HNPs also shows low S Cu and low CO2 conversion, because the ZnO and ZrO2 NPs played as support during the synthesis, and the synthesis method is disadvantageous to disperse the high-loading Cu. On the contrary, in the synthesis of CZZ-HN with MOF skeleton of HKUST-1, Cu atoms were embedded in the MOF structure, and were dispersed well during the sacrificing procedure. Based on the above analysis, MOF type should be consistent with the highest amount of element in the catalyst, which is crucial in creating the metal-oxide interface and enhancing the methanol synthesis performance. The surface valent states are crucial for product selectivities. Yu et al. [22] reported that the metal-oxide interface could enable Cu transformation to Cu+ after reduction, and Cu+ could enhance STYCH3OH by activating CO2 and stabilizing intermediates such as formate. In this work, the STYCH3OH exhibits a positive correlation with the ratio of Cu+/Cutotal as shown in Fig. 11(b), indicating that the metal-oxide interface and the amount of surface Cu+ play a crucial role for STYCH3OH. Moreover, both bulk and surface reduction properties are found to be significant. The surface species with lower reduction temperatures (CZZ-HN, CZZ-ZB, CZZ-CP) as shown in Fig. 5 exhibit higher STYCH3OH compared to the other catalysts. Specifically, CZZ-HN displays the highest A α/(A α+A β) (Table 3) implying the highest degree of metal-oxide interactions, and the lowest surface reduction temperature (Fig. 5) implying a strong interaction between Cu species and the surface metal oxides. Both of these characteristics are likely correlated with the superior STYCH3OH performance observed in CZZ-HN among the investigated catalysts. It is noted that among the investigated MOF-derived catalysts, only CZZ-HN exhibits better performance than CZZ-CP. The MOF-derived catalyst preparation normally requires coordination agent and extra hydrothermal treatment which add to the catalyst production cost. The more complex and more expensive catalyst procedure limits the application of the MOF-derived catalysts. Comparing the catalyst performance with the simple co-precipitation method, only CZZ-HN is a potentially applicable catalyst. In light of the current work, procedure optimization should be undertaken to further improve the MOF-derived catalysts’ performance. 4 Conclusions In this work, five MOF-derived Cu-ZnO-ZrO2 catalysts were prepared and were compared with the catalyst prepared by co-precipitation. The characterization results show that the catalysts derived from ZIF-8 and UiO-66 exhibit a low surface area and large Cu particle size due to the destruction of pore structure caused by high Cu loading. On the contrary, the CZZ-HN catalyst derived from HKUST-1 in which Cu is the metal center in the MOF skeleton exhibits a higher surface area and reduced Cu particle size. The evaluation results imply that the CO2 hydrogenation activity is closely related to the number of surface Cu sites, and different Cu sites influence the product distribution. The surface Cu+ content and the reduction properties (both reflect the metal-oxide interaction) are closely related with STYCH3OH. CZZ-HN displays superior performance (highest STYCH3OH and highest TOFCH3OH) among the investigated catalysts, which could be attributed to the enhanced metal-oxide interface by the MOF-derived synthesis. This study verifies the enhancement of metal-oxide interface by the MOF-derivation method, and inspires further optimization of catalyst structure by matching synthesis formulas and MOF types for various reactions. coredata.dc:description: Metal-oxide interaction is crucial in catalyst performance. Using MOF as precursor can improve the metal-oxide interface on the catalysts. This work explores the properties of the MOF-derived Cu-Zn-Zr catalysts (CZZ-HN, CZZ-C Z-HNPs, CZZ-ZB, CZZ-Z and CZZ-U) in the hydrogenation of CO2 to CH3OH with reference to the conventional catalysts (CZZ-CP) prepared by co-precipitation. The catalyst structure is found to be closely related to the catalyst composition and the MOF type. The evaluation results imply that the CO2 hydrogenation activity is related to the number of surface Cu sites, and different Cu sites influence the product distribution. Among the investigated catalysts, the metal-oxide interface is greatly enhanced on CZZ-HN due to the proper match of element composition and MOF type (high amount of Cu with Cu-MOF precursor), which shows improved STYCH3OH and TOFCH3OH compared with CZZ-CP. This study verifies the enhancement of metal-oxide interface by the MOF-derivation method, and inspires further optimization of catalyst structure by matching synthesis formula and MOF types for various reactions.
coredata.dc:title: MOF-derived Cu-ZnO-ZrO2 catalysts for CH3OH synthesis from CO2 hydrogenation
